Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Collaborative Research: Atomistic Design of High-Performance Epoxidation Catalysts with Atomic Layer Deposition and Kinetic Monte Carlo Simulations

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511820(Lei) & 1510485(Turner)

Direct oxidation of propylene to propylene oxide represents huge potential for a change to much more sustainable production of a molecule that currently has production levels of 9 billion pounds a year. Current production is inherently inefficient using vast amounts of energy and producing significant waste. This work proposes novel catalyst compositions and highly-engineered structures that have the potential to promote the direct oxidation with molecular oxygen at improved selectivity and conversion, and with less energy consumption and environmental waste.

The PIs hypothesize that the stability, selectivity, and efficiency of propylene selective oxidation can be improved by carefully synthesizing Pd-Au and Ag-Au bimetallic nano-catalysts. The new catalysts are expected to benefit from the high selectivity of Au and the high activity of the additional second metal. Au nanoclusters are decorated with surface atoms of Pd or Ag, and the resultant particles are isolated from one another and optimized for interaction with a titanium-silicalite support by the deposition of metal oxide hillocks between the particles. The combination of colloidal synthesis and atomic layer deposition (ALD) will be used to create the highly-engineered structures. Synchrotron X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy, and atomic-scale kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) calculations will be employed to potentially reveal a dynamic picture of the working catalysts and precisely identify the mechanistic role of the second metal.

If successful, these catalysts could be a a game-changer for the propylene oxide industry. In addition the study will provide valuable understanding of the potential role of bimetaliic catalysts of this type for other large-scale industrial chemical reactions. The study will achieve educational outreach by providing support to two graduate students and also undergraduate students at two institutions within the state of Alabama. Another outreach component is field trips by both undergraduate and graduate researchers to catalyst manufacturing sites and commercial R&D centers in the Huntsville area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Propylene oxide derived from propylene is a key chemical intermediate for the production of a number of commodity chemicals, including polyol, propylene glycol, and glycol ethers. In this combined experimental and theoretical work, we systematically investigated well-defined catalyst structures and performance relationships to the direct propylene epoxidation in the presence of oxygen and hydrogen.

In the experimental work, we utilized atomic precision synthesis technique atomic layer deposition and synchrotron X-ray based characterization technique X-ray absorption spectroscopy to establish precise structure-performance relationship of gold/titania based catalysts for propylene epoxidation to propylene oxide. The reactivity as a function of Ti coordination was established by using these two techniques. The atomistic simulations performed by the collaborations with the computational team at the University of Alabama were seamlessly integrated with the experimental results to provide detail understandings of the reaction mechanisms and kinetics.

In terms of gold catalyst synthesis, we invented a rapid, convenient method to synthesize small gold nanoparticles with >90% gold uptake efficiency. As compared to the frequently used deposition precipitation which has a 1% - 20% gold uptake efficiency, the newly developed technique significantly minimizes the waste of gold precursors. The catalyst prepared using the new synthesis method exhibited one of the highest activity and selectivity in the literature.

In addition, we also developed a technique to facilitate evaporation of low volatility chemicals for atomic layer deposition using ultrasonic atomization. This technique opens a new window to develop novel atomic layer deposition processes using low volatility and unstable precursors such as gold precursors.

The experimental side of the project has engaged seven graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, and nine undergraduate students in performing their research in a multidisciplinary team. The experimental system was used during the summers to host seven traditionally underrepresented high school researchers in a six-week mentor/apprentice program. The students and PIs gained unique experience by carrying out the highly integrated collaborations between the experimental work at The University of Alabama in Huntsville and the computational work. Research results were presented in peer-reviewed articles, national conferences, and invention disclosures.
